document.title: On the Average of Triangular Numbers

creator.personname: Mario CatalaniDepartment of Economics, University of TorinoVia Po 53, 10124 Torino, Italymario.catalani@unito.it

abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: The problem we are dealing with is the following: find two sequences an and bn such that the average of the first bn triangular numbers (starting with the triangular number 1) is still a triangular number, precisely the an-th triangular number. We get also some side results: for instance one of the sequence instrumental to finding the asked for sequences turns out to be a bisection of the sequence of the numerators of continued fraction convergents to 3.

para.p: The present note has been suggested by a problem proposed in the ”Student Problems” section of The Mathematical Gazette (see []). The problem we tackle is the following: find two sequences an and bn such that the average of the first bn triangular numbers (starting with the triangular number 1) is still a triangular number, precisely the an-th triangular number.
If we want that the average of the first s triangular number be a triangular number it has to hold
for some positive integer r. This becomes
that is, clearing the fractions,
Solving for s and considering that s has to be a positive quantity we have the solution
Now because s has to be an integer we need r such that +1⁢12r⁢12r2 is a perfect square; also -+1⁢12r⁢12r23 has to be even.
Consider the nonhomogeneous recurrence =wn⁢wkrs defined by

Math.text: formulae@(w _ n = (4 * w _ (n - 1) - w _ (n - 2)) + k, formulae@(w _ 0 = r, w _ 1 = s))

para.p: Let α and β be the zeros of the polynomial +-x2⁢4x1, that is =α+23=β-23. Note that =+αβ4=⁢αβ1=-αβ⁢23=+α2β214.
It is useful to introduce the homogeneous sequence =Ln⁢w0 24 given by
This sequence is the analogous in this context of the Lucas numbers. The closed form of Ln is

Math.text: L _ n = alpha ^ n + beta ^ n

para.p: The generating function of wn is given by
from which we get the closed form

Math.text: w _ n = (- k / 2) + (((s * alpha + ((k + 4 * r) - s) * beta + k) - 2 * r) / 12) * alpha ^ n + (((s * beta + ((k + 4 * r) - s) * alpha + k) - 2 * r) / 12) * beta ^ n

para.p: It may be useful to write the RHS in terms of the Ln sequence
Now introduce the sequence =an⁢w1 0 1. an is sequence A061278 in []: the first values are 0 1 5 20 76 285…. Using Equation we get
Note that

Math.text: (L _ n) ^ 2 = (alpha ^ n + beta ^ n) ^ 2 = alpha ^ (2 * n) + beta ^ (2 * n) + 2 = L _ (2 * n) + 2

L _ n * L _ (n + 1) = (alpha ^ n + beta ^ n) * (alpha ^ (n + 1) + beta ^ (n + 1)) = alpha ^ (2 * n + 1) + alpha ^ n * beta ^ (n + 1) + alpha ^ (n + 1) * beta ^ n + beta ^ (2 * n + 1) = L _ (2 * n + 1) + alpha + beta = L _ (2 * n + 1) + 4.
alpha ^ (2 * n + 1) + alpha ^ n * beta ^ (n + 1) + alpha ^ (n + 1) * beta ^ n + beta ^ (2 * n + 1)

where we used the recurrence defining Ln. Now we are going to show that this expression is a perfect square. Write
Hence it remains to prove that

Math.text: u _ n = (1 / square-root@(2)) * alpha ^ (n + 1 / 2) - (1 / square-root@(2)) * beta ^ (n + 1 / 2)

para.p: is a positive integer. This will be done by strong induction. First of all note that
so that we will take =-α12β122. Then =u01. Next assume that un is a positive integer for ≤nn0. It follows that =⁢un0+αβ⁢4un0 is a positive integer. But

Math.text: u _ n _ 0 * (alpha + beta) = (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ (n _ 0 + 1 / 2) - beta ^ (n _ 0 + 1 / 2)) * (alpha + beta) = ((1 / square-root@(2)) * alpha ^ (n _ 0 + 1 + 1 / 2) + (1 / square-root@(2)) * alpha ^ (n _ 0 + 1 / 2) * beta) - (1 / square-root@(2)) * alpha * beta ^ (n _ 0 + 1 / 2) - (1 / square-root@(2)) * beta ^ (n _ 0 + 1 + 1 / 2) = (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ (n _ 0 + 1 + 1 / 2) - beta ^ (n _ 0 + 1 + 1 / 2)) + (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ (n _ 0 - 1 / 2) - beta ^ (n _ 0 - 1 / 2)) = (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ (n _ 0 + 1 + 1 / 2) - beta ^ (n _ 0 + 1 + 1 / 2)) + (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ ((n _ 0 - 1) + 1 / 2) - beta ^ ((n _ 0 - 1) + 1 / 2)) = u _ (n _ 0 + 1) + u _ (n _ 0 - 1)

((1 / square-root@(2)) * alpha ^ (n _ 0 + 1 + 1 / 2) + (1 / square-root@(2)) * alpha ^ (n _ 0 + 1 / 2) * beta) - (1 / square-root@(2)) * alpha * beta ^ (n _ 0 + 1 / 2) - (1 / square-root@(2)) * beta ^ (n _ 0 + 1 + 1 / 2)

para.p: Because by the induction hypothesis u-n01 is a positive integer, it follows that u+n01 is a positive integer. This ends the induction proof.
As a side result we get that un obeys the recurrence

Math.text: formulae@(u _ n = 4 * u _ (n - 1) - u _ (n - 2), formulae@(u _ 0 = 1, u _ 1 = 5))

para.p: since -α32β32=50=⁢52. un is sequence A001834 in [].

It remains to prove that un is odd which is the same as to prove that L+⁢2n12 is even, which means that L+⁢2n1 is a multiple of 4. Again this will be done by strong induction. For =n0 we have =L14. Next assume that L+⁢2n1 is a multiple of 4 for ≤nn0, that is =L+⁢2n1⁢4cn, where cn is a positive integer. Then

Math.text: alpha ^ (2 * n _ 0 + 3) + alpha ^ (2 * n _ 0 + 1) * beta ^ 2 + alpha ^ 2 * beta ^ (2 * n _ 0 + 1) + beta ^ (2 * n _ 0 + 3)

And finally we have

It is interesting the fact that the sequence un is a bisection of sequence A002531 in [] that gives the numerators of continued fraction convergents to 3, a result that as far as we know is new. Denoting by zn the sequence of the convergents we are going to prove
From the comments to A002531 in [] we have that
Now

Math.text: u _ n - u _ (n - 1) = (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ (n + 1 / 2) - beta ^ (n + 1 / 2)) - (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ (n - 1 / 2) - beta ^ (n - 1 / 2)) = (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ n * (alpha ^ (1 / 2) - alpha ^ (- 1 / 2)) + beta ^ n * (beta ^ (- 1 / 2) - beta ^ (1 / 2))) = (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ n * (alpha ^ (1 / 2) - beta ^ (1 / 2)) + beta ^ n * (alpha ^ (1 / 2) - beta ^ (1 / 2))) = (1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ n + beta ^ n) * (alpha ^ (1 / 2) - beta ^ (1 / 2))
(1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ n * (alpha ^ (1 / 2) - alpha ^ (- 1 / 2)) + beta ^ n * (beta ^ (- 1 / 2) - beta ^ (1 / 2)))
(1 / square-root@(2)) * (alpha ^ n * (alpha ^ (1 / 2) - beta ^ (1 / 2)) + beta ^ n * (alpha ^ (1 / 2) - beta ^ (1 / 2)))
